history.content:
Usually you AI first, but there's no set order.  It's just that being an AI and/or a tutor/reader helps your chances of becoming a TA.  


———————————


With that being said, AI is on a lower level compared to reader/tutor as the former have no pay and the latter does.
Usually you AI first, but there's no set order.  It's just that being an AI and/or a tutor/reader helps your chances of becoming a TA.

children.subject:
This will be my fourth semester as a TA. I'd say the 'suggested' (but longest) route is to AI (because this is attainable; there's no filtering out through the application), then CSM, then tutor/reader, then TA. However, at any point you could jump to any of the different steps.

For me, I joined CSM as a sophomore, and the same semester was accepted to be a tutor for the same class I was teaching for CSM. The next year, I became a TA for the same course. I spent a year teaching that class before deciding to switch to another course (a common occurrence). For the lower divs, a lot of it is random chance, unfortunately. For instance, I started at tutor and moved to TA after two semesters; other people spend 1-2 semesters more before getting a tutor position. Others go straight to TA. It all really depends.

But to answer your question:

1) You should take CS370; I have heard very good things, and as someone who has been involved in the CSM recruitment+course staff hiring process, we do consider it a positive.

2) I would highly recommend joining CSM (though it has gotten more competitive unfortunately) for its community of people in CS who teach, and for its systematic curriculum which helps build good teaching practices. It's not that it's always clear who amongst upper-div TAs have received 'formalized' training through CSM or other experience, and who are simply really great students, but certainly those of us who went through CSM all have a strong foundation and many have a genuine passion for teaching (which I have found to be a large factor in being a good TA).

3) If it's too late for you to do either of those things this semester, AI for a course you're interested in teaching. There are also other teaching clubs; ANova, BEAM, OASES, etc

Something I'd ask is: why do you want to become a TA? Is it to improve the student experience? Do you just want it for your resume? Would you like to learn the material more deeply? Is it the salary? Being a TA is an incredibly rewarding experience, and as I'm sure you've felt yourself, good TAs can make or break your semester. I'd encourage you to consider your own reasons since you seem to be set on becoming a TA.
How long does it usually take one to become a TA? and what courses/work experience do they pursue to do so? Also, can you continue being a TA once you graduate?

I think one of the reasons there might be “conflicting” information is because the process is professor/class dependent, and different professors hire differently.

Some professors will hire based on the recommendation of the previous course staff, some based on head TAs recommendations, some may have a more formalized process based on teaching experience, etc.

Reader/Tutor: If the class has a reader position, become one! Becoming a reader, actively participating and being proactive in doing more is a sure way to becoming a TA (this will usually get you hired the subsequent semester as a TA if you are very proactive, e.g. CS70, CS170). I'm not sure about classes with tutor positions, but I'm assuming the same thing hold there.

CSM: CSM is also a great way to gain some teaching experience, meet similarly minded student-teachers, and helps in TA applications. I personally think my first semester with CSM helped green light my TA application the subsequent semester.

AI: I would actually not suggest becoming an AI. I did it for one semester and did not find the experience that interesting or helpful (as I was just debugging people's python code for CS61A). I'm additionally not sure how much it helps with TA applications.

CS370: I don't know if it helps in TA applications, I personally did not take it and still got TA offers after a double semester with CSM. That said, it is possible it does help.

Tldr: I would highly suggest becoming a reader and being proactive in that role next semester. For some reason readers are a very under-talked about/under-appreciated way in gaining course staff experience and becoming a TA.

As the Head TA who managed hiring CS Spring 2020 188 TAs. Here are the things I personally looked for.

1. Exceptional academic record. Usually this means an A+ in the class you intend to TA in, and an array of A/A+ in other CS classes. This is a good indicator that you have a solid grip on the material, and is likely to maintain control over your classes throughout the semester.

2. Reader/tutor in the past. Since 188 usually don’t usually hire readers or tutors, we inquired the performance of these students in their previous course staff experience. Being a lab assistant will probably not help your application (because lots of people have it)

3. A passion for CS education. Let’s be honest, lots of us could be a TA, but very few of us are willing to throw ourselves completely into designing and optimizing the course. I look for the candidate’s potential to grow, which is largely determined by how much they care about teaching.

Pro tip: become a first-time TA in the Summer. Usually summer TA positions have less competition but the responsibilities are just as challenging. That’s a good place to get your first offer.

history.content: Can someone clarify the path to becoming a course TA? To my understanding it's course tutor/reader --> academic intern --> TA, but I've heard conflicting answers :/ Thanks!
